description: Represents an individual associated with a campaign or business. Contacts are linked to Accounts and can be involved in campaigns, sales processes, and customer support interactions. They contain key information like demographics, preferences, and engagement history, helping marketers target and personalize campaigns effectively.

fields.description: Lookup field to the Account. This field ensures that each Contact is associated with an Account, establishing the relationship between a Contact and their parent organization or company.

Text field used to categorize contacts for filtering and segmentation. Stores a label that identifies what group/type the contact belongs to (e.g., CRMantra, Customer, Prospect, Partner, Internal, Demo). Commonly used for campaign targeting and reporting.
The name of the assistant associated with the contact, if applicable.
The phone number of the assistant associated with the contact, if applicable.
The birthdate of the contact, useful for personalized marketing or demographic profiling.
Lookup field to the User who owns this contact record, typically the sales or support representative responsible for the contact.
Lookup field to the User who created this contact record.
Picklist field to capture the source from which the contact was acquired (e.g., web form, referral, event).
A reference to the contact’s data from Data.com (formerly Jigsaw), useful for data enrichment.
The department within the contact’s organization, which can be used for segmentation in campaigns.
A long text area where additional details about the contact can be added, such as preferences, interests, or history with the organization.
A checkbox that indicates whether the contact has opted out of phone communication.
The contact’s email address, used for email marketing and communication.
A checkbox that indicates whether the contact has opted out of email communications.
The contact’s fax number, used for communication when necessary.
A checkbox that indicates whether the contact has opted out of receiving fax communications.
A picklist field to capture the gender identity of the contact for demographic profiling or targeted marketing.
The home phone number of the contact, used for personal outreach or emergency contact.
Lookup field to the Individual object. This field allows associating a contact with an individual entity, useful in cases where the contact is a member of a family or other grouping.
The languages spoken by the contact, useful for targeted campaigns in different regions or for multilingual outreach.
Lookup field to the User who last modified this contact record.
Date and time when the contact made the last 'Stay-in-Touch' request, useful for managing communication frequency.
Date and time when the contact's 'Stay-in-Touch' information was last updated, useful for tracking engagement.
Picklist field to capture the source of the lead that generated this contact, e.g., web, phone, event.
Picklist field that can capture the contact's seniority level within their organization, useful for segmentation.
The mailing address of the contact, useful for direct mail campaigns or regional targeting.
The mobile phone number of the contact, used for SMS marketing and notifications.
The full name of the contact, typically a combination of the first and last name fields.
The contact’s salutation, such as Mr., Mrs., or Dr., used for personalized communication.
The first name of the contact, used for personalized communications.
The last name of the contact, used for personalization in communications.
The contact’s alternative address, if applicable, useful for direct mail or special campaigns.
The contact’s other phone number, which can be used as an alternative for communication.
The primary phone number of the contact, used for general communication.
The pronouns used by the contact, helping to personalize communication and show respect for identity.
Lookup field to the contact’s supervisor or manager, providing hierarchical context.
The job title or position of the contact, used for segmentation or personalized outreach.

The date when the contact's employment/role started at the company. DO NOT use this field for filtering active/current contacts - only End_Date__c is used for that purpose. This field is NOT related to CampaignMember.Status.

The date when the contact's employment/role ends at the company. ACTIVE CONTACT FILTER: You MUST use BOTH conditions with OR: WHERE (End_Date__c = null OR End_Date__c >= TODAY). This includes contacts with no end date (null) AND contacts with future end dates (>= TODAY). NEVER use only 'End_Date__c = null' - you will miss active contacts with future end dates. If user says 'ALL contacts', do NOT apply any filter.condition must be (End_Date__c = null OR End_Date__c >= TODAY) not give it partially completely need to be present ****IMPORTANT****

description: Represents a marketing campaign used for tracking and organizing marketing efforts, such as product promotions, events, or outreach programs. The Campaign object allows for tracking costs, revenue, responses, and related records like leads, opportunities, and contacts.

fields.description: Indicates whether the campaign is currently active. If the campaign is active, it will be used in marketing operations; otherwise, it is archived.
The actual cost of the campaign. This value is updated to reflect the true expenses incurred during the campaign's execution.
The total actual cost of the campaign including costs from its child campaigns, representing the full scope of expenses.
The initial budget allocated to the campaign, representing the planned expenses.
The total budget of the campaign including the budgets of its child campaigns, representing the overall financial scope of the campaign.
Lookup to the Record Type that defines the type of campaign member (e.g., contact, lead). This field helps differentiate different types of campaign members in a marketing effort.
The name of the campaign, used to identify and track the campaign within Salesforce. Typically reflects the campaign's focus or goal.
Lookup to the User who owns the campaign. The campaign owner is typically the person responsible for managing and executing the campaign.
The total number of contacts associated with the campaign. This field can be used to track how many people are being targeted in the campaign.
The total number of contacts involved in the campaign including those from child campaigns, providing a full view of the campaign’s reach.
The number of leads that were converted as a result of the campaign, tracking the campaign’s success in generating sales-qualified leads.
The number of converted leads from the parent campaign and its child campaigns, giving a comprehensive view of lead conversion across multiple campaign levels.
Lookup to the User who created the campaign record, typically used for auditing and tracking the record's origin.
A long text field where additional information or notes about the campaign can be stored, such as goals, target audience, or campaign strategy.
Stores the email template identifier to be used for this Campaign (e.g. the template ID for campaign email communications).
The end date of the campaign, indicating when the campaign is scheduled to close.
The expected response rate for the campaign, usually expressed as a percentage. This helps measure the anticipated effectiveness of the campaign.
The projected revenue that the campaign is expected to generate, based on forecasts or assumptions.
The total expected revenue of the campaign, including revenue from child campaigns, giving a full picture of the financial expectations for the entire campaign hierarchy.
Lookup to the User who last modified the campaign record, useful for auditing and tracking changes.
The total number of leads associated with the campaign, indicating how many individuals were targeted through lead generation activities.
The total number of leads involved in the campaign including those from child campaigns, providing a full view of lead volume across the hierarchy.
The number of messages sent as part of this campaign (system-calculated where applicable).
The number of messages sent for the parent campaign and its child campaigns combined (system-calculated where applicable).
The number of opportunities generated by the campaign, reflecting the campaign’s impact on sales.
The number of opportunities generated by the campaign including child campaigns, providing a full view across the campaign hierarchy.
Lookup to the Parent Campaign, if this campaign is part of a hierarchy. This allows for campaign rollups to track data across parent-child relationships.
The number of responses received from contacts or leads as part of the campaign. This could be an indicator of engagement or interest in the campaign.
The number of responses received across the parent campaign and its child campaigns combined.
The start date of the campaign, indicating when the campaign activities are scheduled to begin.
The current status of the campaign. This field helps track the progress of the campaign.
The type of the campaign used for categorization and reporting purposes.
The total value of all opportunities associated with the campaign, showing the overall potential revenue generated by the campaign’s opportunities.
The total value of all opportunities associated with the parent campaign and its child campaigns combined.
The total value of the opportunities that have been won as a result of the campaign, providing a view of the campaign's success in generating actual sales.
The total value of all won opportunities across the parent campaign and its child campaigns combined.
The number of opportunities that were won during the campaign, representing a successful outcome.
The number of won opportunities across the parent campaign and its child campaigns combined.

description: Represents an individual’s association with a campaign. A CampaignMember object links a Contact, Lead, or Person Account with a Campaign, tracking their participation, response status, and engagement with the marketing effort.

fields.description: Lookup field to the associated Campaign. This links the campaign member to the specific Campaign they are a part of.
The city where the campaign member resides or is located. This can be useful for regional targeting and segmentation in marketing efforts.
The name of the company or organization the campaign member belongs to, representing their associated **Account** in Salesforce.
Lookup field to the Contact associated with this Campaign Member. This links a contact to a specific campaign, tracking their engagement and participation.
The country where the campaign member is located. This field can be used for geographic segmentation and international marketing strategies.
Lookup field to the User who created the Campaign Member record. This is used for tracking record ownership and auditing.
The date and time when the Campaign Member record was created. This can be used for tracking when a contact or lead was associated with the campaign.
A long text field that can store additional information about the Campaign Member, such as notes on their participation, behavior, or engagement level in the campaign.
Checkbox indicating whether the campaign member has opted out of phone calls. This helps comply with privacy regulations and user preferences.
The email address of the campaign member, used for email communications and digital marketing efforts.
A checkbox indicating whether the campaign member has opted out of receiving email communications as part of the campaign.
The fax number of the campaign member, used for fax-based marketing or notifications, if applicable.
A checkbox indicating whether the campaign member has opted out of receiving fax communications as part of the campaign.
The first name of the campaign member, used for personalization in email and other marketing communications.
The date when the campaign member first responded to the campaign, useful for tracking engagement and follow-up activities.
Lookup field to the User who last modified the Campaign Member record. This field helps with record auditing and tracking changes over time.
The date and time when the Campaign Member record was last modified. This is useful for tracking the most recent updates to engagement and status.
The last name of the campaign member, used for personalization and identifying the individual within the campaign.
Lookup field to the Lead associated with this Campaign Member. This is relevant for campaigns that target Leads as well as Contacts.
Picklist field indicating the source from which the Lead or Contact was acquired. This helps measure campaign success by tracking lead generation sources.
The mobile phone number of the campaign member, useful for SMS marketing or personalized mobile outreach.
The primary phone number of the campaign member, used for phone-based outreach or communication.
Checkbox indicating whether the campaign member has responded to the campaign, helping to track engagement and conversion.
The salutation of the campaign member used for respectful communication in personalized marketing.
The state or province where the campaign member is located. This field can be used for regional targeting in campaigns.

Picklist field that tracks the EMAIL CAMPAIGN ENGAGEMENT status of the campaign member (e.g., whether the email was Sent, Received, or they Responded). IMPORTANT: This field is NOT for employment status. To filter contacts who are currently working at the company, use the Contact object's Start_Date__c and End_Date__c fields instead. Values like 'Sent', 'Responded', 'Planned' indicate email campaign activity, not whether someone is actively employed.
The street address of the campaign member, useful for direct mail campaigns or location-based outreach.
The job title of the campaign member, useful for segmentation and targeting based on their position within an organization.
The postal code of the campaign member’s location, useful for geographic segmentation and regional targeting in campaigns.

description: Represents the set of allowed Campaign Member Status values for a specific Campaign. These records control what values appear in the Campaign Member 'Status' picklist for that Campaign, and which one is the default.

fields.description: System-generated unique identifier for the Campaign Member Status record.
Indicates whether the record has been deleted (soft-deleted).
Lookup to the Campaign that this status set belongs to. Status values are stored per Campaign.
The status label shown to users in the Campaign Member Status dropdown (for this Campaign). Example: Draft, Sent, Responded.
Controls the display order of statuses in the Campaign Member Status dropdown (lower numbers appear first).
If true, this status becomes the default value when a new Campaign Member is created for this Campaign. Only one status per Campaign should be marked as default.
If true, this status is treated as a 'Responded' status for campaign reporting and response metrics.

description: Represents a potential sales opportunity or prospect. Leads are typically used to track unqualified potential customers, and once qualified, they are converted into an Account, Contact, or Opportunity.

fields.description: The mailing address of the lead. This field helps in targeting leads for location-based campaigns.
The annual revenue of the company associated with the lead. Used for segmenting leads based on company size.
The name of the company associated with the lead, useful for B2B sales and identifying target organizations.
The D-U-N-S number for the company, which is a unique identifier for businesses used in global databases.
Lookup to the User who created the lead record. Helps track lead ownership and record creation history.
Custom field capturing the current generators or products of interest for the lead, useful for tailoring outreach strategies.
Lookup to the D&B Company record, which provides additional business data about the lead from Dun & Bradstreet.
The Data.com key for the lead, used to enrich the lead data from Data.com (now a part of Salesforce).
A long text field used to store detailed notes or additional information about the lead, such as interests, needs, or history.
Checkbox indicating whether the lead has opted out of phone calls. Important for compliance and respecting customer preferences.
The email address of the lead. Used for **email marketing**, outreach, and nurturing.
A checkbox indicating whether the lead has opted out of receiving email communications.
The fax number for the lead, used for fax-based marketing (less common today, but may still be in use in some industries).
A checkbox indicating whether the lead has opted out of receiving fax communications.
Picklist field capturing the gender identity of the lead, useful for demographic segmentation in campaigns.
Lookup to the Individual object. This field allows associating the lead with an individual entity, useful for personal outreach.
The industry in which the lead operates. This is useful for B2B sales teams for segmenting leads by sector or industry.
Lookup to the User who last modified the lead record. This helps with tracking changes to the record and user accountability.
The last date the lead was transferred between users or sales representatives.
Lookup to the User or Group who owns the lead record, representing the sales rep or team responsible for the lead.
Picklist field indicating the source from which the lead was acquired  . This helps track lead generation effectiveness.
Picklist field that tracks the current status of the lead (e.g., New, Working, Converted). This field is essential for managing lead pipeline.
The mobile phone number of the lead, used for SMS marketing, mobile outreach, and quick communication.
The full name of the lead, typically a combination of the first and last name fields, used for personalization and identification.
The salutation used when addressing the lead in communications.
The first name of the lead, used for personalized communications and outreach.
The last name of the lead, used for addressing the lead and personalizing communications.
The number of employees in the lead's company, used to segment leads by company size for targeting purposes.
The number of locations for the lead’s company, helping to understand the scale of the business.
The primary phone number of the lead, used for outreach and communication.
Picklist field indicating whether this lead is considered a primary contact for the associated company or account.
Picklist to capture the products or services the lead is interested in, useful for segmentation and targeted sales outreach.
Picklist to capture the pronouns used by the lead, helping to personalize communication and show respect for identity.
Picklist field to rate the lead's quality or readiness for conversion, useful for prioritizing leads in the sales process.
The Standard Industry Classification (SIC) code for the lead's company, used for segmenting leads by industry or vertical.
The job title of the lead, helping to personalize outreach and provide context on their role within the organization.
The website URL for the lead’s company, useful for researching the lead and understanding their business.

description: An Account represents a company, individual, or another entity associated with your organization. It serves as a central repository for tracking customer data, managing business interactions, and integrating other records like contracts, opportunities, and related activities. The Account object is critical for establishing long-term relationships, sales cycles, and ensuring personalized engagement based on business metrics and attributes.

fields.description: The name of the account. This field is essential for identifying and referencing the account across all business processes and reports. It is used in customer-related reports and helps in differentiating one account from another within the organization’s Salesforce system.

A unique identifier for the account, usually assigned by the organization for internal purposes. This helps in referencing the account within Salesforce for reporting, contract management, and ensuring that any activity related to the account is easily traceable across multiple systems.

This field defines the type of account within Salesforce, distinguishing between types such as customers, partners, prospects, or others. It allows the organization to tailor business processes, reporting, and workflows based on the nature of the account.

The physical location or site associated with the account. This could include the address of an office, manufacturing facility, or retail store. The location might influence business decisions, such as product distribution, regional pricing, or customized offerings based on the site’s specific needs.

Indicates the origin of the account, such as through a referral, marketing campaign, or inbound inquiry. Tracking the source of an account is vital for analyzing the effectiveness of different lead-generation channels and strategies, providing valuable insights into the ROI of marketing activities.

The total annual revenue of the account, expressed in the specified currency. This metric helps in determining the size and financial potential of the account. Higher annual revenue might influence business strategies, contract terms, and discounting decisions during contract renewals or new deals.

This formula field stores the account's billing address as a text string, which might be useful for automation, processing, or reporting purposes. It consolidates address information from multiple fields and presents it as a single, easily-accessible value. This field is especially important for invoicing, billing cycles, and contract renewals where the billing address is critical.

The complete billing address associated with the account, including street, city, state, and postal code. This field is crucial for invoicing, delivering physical goods or services, and providing proper shipping and billing instructions. It is also used for generating reports and analytics related to sales performance and business activity by location.

The level within the channel program that the account is associated with. For example, it could indicate whether the account is part of a bronze, silver, or gold tier. This categorization helps in determining how different levels of customers are treated in terms of discounts, access to exclusive offers, and the level of customer support they receive.

The name of the specific channel program associated with the account. This program might offer the account access to specific incentives, rebates, or partner opportunities. Tracking this allows the business to segment accounts based on their involvement in different channel programs and optimize the renewal or upsell process accordingly.

Indicates whether the account is enabled for portal access. If true, the account has the ability to manage certain interactions, such as reviewing contracts, submitting support tickets, or accessing account-related data, through a secure, self-service portal. This is particularly important for accounts that prefer managing their engagement independently or are involved in complex contract renewals.

A unique identifier for the account within Data.com (formerly Jigsaw). This identifier can be used to link and enrich account data by pulling in additional information from external sources, providing a more complete profile of the account for strategic decision-making and outreach.

A long-form text field that provides detailed information about the account’s business, operations, history, or other pertinent context. This description can help internal teams understand the nuances of working with the account, including any specific conditions or considerations for contract renewals or business development.

This field denotes the tier or classification of the account, which can have a significant impact on how business processes are managed. Tiers may be based on the account's business size, importance, or strategic alignment with the organization. For example, enterprise-level accounts might receive customized services or pricing, while smaller accounts may follow standardized procedures.

The total number of employees at the account’s business location. Larger accounts may have more complex business needs, requiring tailored solutions and contracts. This metric also helps in understanding the scale of the account's operations and its potential for additional business opportunities or contract renewals.

The fax number associated with the account. While not commonly used in modern business, fax numbers might still be relevant for certain contracts, communications, or legal documentation processes that require physical document transmission, especially for industries that still rely on fax as a secure method of communication.

The geographical coordinates (latitude and longitude) of the account’s location. These coordinates are essential for geographic analysis, regional marketing strategies, and logistical purposes, such as managing product deliveries or determining the proximity of other accounts in the same region.

A formula field representing the account's geographical location in textual form. This field is helpful for reporting, analytics, and understanding regional distribution. It could be used in contract renewals or notifications where specific geographic regions trigger certain conditions.

The industry type of the account, selected from a predefined list. Knowing the industry helps in customizing business offerings, understanding market conditions, and predicting the account's needs during contract renewals. It may also impact pricing, product offerings, and the terms of renewal.

Indicates the ownership structure of the account, whether it’s private, public, or government. This can have a significant impact on the contract renewal terms, with government accounts possibly having specific regulatory compliance needs, while private companies might negotiate differently based on business objectives.

The ID of the parent account, if the current account is part of a larger parent-child relationship. This field is crucial for multi-level accounts, where renewal strategies might differ based on the hierarchical relationship between the accounts, especially in corporate structures.

Indicates whether the account is a partner organization. Partners may have special business agreements, contracts, or terms that differ from regular customer accounts. This field helps identify strategic relationships and manage renewals or special considerations for those accounts.

The payment terms associated with the account, such as net 30, net 60, or customized payment schedules. This field is critical for managing financial aspects of the relationship, such as payment cycles and renewal billing schedules. It ensures that the business and customer align on payment expectations.

The phone number associated with the account, used as a direct communication channel for support, billing inquiries, and contract management. It’s a primary method of contact, particularly for resolving issues related to contract renewals or business matters.

The category of Points of Interest (POI) linked to the account. POIs could include specific business operations, such as retail locations or data centers. Identifying these points helps in creating location-specific contracts or renewal strategies for businesses with multiple facilities or assets.

The URL for an image related to the account’s Points of Interest. This image may be tied to a physical location, event, or other significant business assets that are relevant for business operations, including contract renewals, service agreements, or promotions.

A list of Points of Interest (POIs) associated with the account. This could include facilities, stores, or business locations relevant to the account’s operations. It’s used for location-specific strategies and helps identify assets or locations that may impact the contract renewal process.

A subcategory under Points of Interest that provides further detail about the type of POI. This helps categorize business locations or assets for more tailored contract management, renewal decisions, or marketing initiatives.

The ID of the premises associated with the account, which could be relevant for accounts with physical locations tied to contracts. This helps in managing location-specific services and logistics, which may influence contract renewals or pricing.

The rating or assessment assigned to the account based on business criteria. This field helps prioritize accounts for services, identify key renewal opportunities, or decide which accounts need special attention during contract negotiations.

The shipping address associated with the account. This address is used for physical deliveries, product shipments, or other logistics tied to contract execution. It also plays a role in invoicing and contract renewals involving physical products or materials.

The Standard Industry Classification (SIC) code for the account’s business sector. This helps categorize accounts by their industry type, allowing the organization to customize renewal offers or pricing strategies based on industry-specific needs.

A description of the SIC code, providing more context about the account’s industry. This aids in understanding which industry-specific terms or conditions should be considered when managing contract renewals.

The stock ticker symbol for publicly traded accounts. This symbol is used for financial tracking and market analysis, potentially impacting renewal pricing strategies based on the company’s stock performance.

The type or category of the account, such as customer, prospect, or partner. This influences how the organization engages with the account and determines the terms of service, contract renewals, or business offers.

The URL of the account’s website. This is helpful for researching the account’s online presence, providing context during contract renewals, or offering additional services related to digital engagement.

recordtype.description: Used to classify an Account as an Advertiser for media campaigns, budget management, and billing purposes.
Represents an advertising Agency involved in planning or purchasing media on behalf of Advertisers.
This is the record type to distinguish Account records that represent a Point of Interest (POI), such as store locations or business branches relevant for geographic targeting.

description: Represents a proposal or a price quote that is provided to a customer, detailing the items or services being offered, including quantities, prices, discounts, and terms.

fields.description: The account associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Account object.
The account associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Account object.
Additional address information for the quote.
Additional name information for the quote.
A formula field that calculates or stores the agency name associated with the quote.
The billing address associated with the quote.
The contact to bill for the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Contact object.
The name to bill for the quote.
The total budget for the quote in the specified currency.
The status of the calculation for the quote, such as whether it is calculated, in progress, or failed.
The end date for the campaign associated with the quote.
The start date for the campaign associated with the quote.
The contact associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Contact object.
A long text area providing a description of the quote.
The discount applied to the quote, represented as a percentage.
The email address associated with the quote.
The expiration date for the quote.
The fax number associated with the quote.
The grand total for the quote in the specified currency.
The date and time when the quote was last priced.
The legal entity associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Legal Entity object.
The total number of line items associated with the quote, calculated as a roll-up summary.
The maximum spend per period for the quote, represented as a percentage.
The minimum margin percentage for the quote.
The minimum spend per period for the quote, represented as a percentage.
The opportunity associated with the quote, referenced by a master-detail relationship to the Opportunity object.
The original action type associated with the quote, such as a renewal or new sale.
The user or group that owns the quote, referenced by a lookup to the User or Group object.
The ID of the parent quote, if this quote is a child of another.
The partner account associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Account object.
The phone number associated with the quote.
The pricing contract associated with the quote, referenced by a lookup to the Contract object.
The duration of the proposal associated with the quote, represented as a picklist value.
The proposed annual contract value associated with the quote, represented as a picklist value.
The name of the quote, used to identify it.
A unique identifier for the quote, automatically generated by Salesforce.
The record type associated with the quote, referencing a Record Type.
The shipping address associated with the quote.
The name associated with the shipping address of the quote.
The type of sales transaction associated with the quote.
The shipping address associated with the quote.
The name associated with the shipping address of the quote.
The cost for shipping and handling associated with the quote.
The start date for the quote.
The status of the quote, such as draft, approved, or expired.
The subtotal for the quote, calculated as a roll-up summary from Quote Line Items.
Indicates whether the quote is currently syncing with another system.
The tax amount associated with the quote.
The total price of the quote, calculated as a roll-up summary from Quote Line Items.
The total price of the quote including tax.
The total tax amount for the quote, calculated as a roll-up summary from Quote Line Items.
The result of quote validation, such as success or failure.
The version number of the quote.

recordtype.description: Used for managing Quotes related to advertising sales, including media plans and campaigns.
Used for creating Quotes tied to resource allocation, staffing, or internal planning operations.

description: Represents a line item within a quote, detailing the product or service being offered, including pricing, quantities, and other relevant attributes.

fields.description: The advertising format associated with the quote line item, represented as a formula.
Test field for storing advertising format information.
Lookup field to the Ad Placement Definition, which defines where the ad will be placed.
The ad server associated with the quote line item.
The size of the ad, represented as a formula.
Long text area containing the selected values for product attributes.
The frequency of billing for this quote line item, such as monthly or annually.
A reference field for the billing associated with this quote line item.
Lookup field to the Billing Treatment, defining how the billing is handled for this line item.
The target for binding the instance, such as an associated quote line item or asset.
The end date of the campaign or pricing for the quote line item.
The start date of the campaign or pricing for the quote line item.
Lookup to the CRMA Lineitem Group, categorizing the quote line item.
Custom name for the product associated with this quote line item.
The date when the service or product is provided or activated.
The discount applied to this quote line item, represented as a currency value.
The discount applied to this quote line item, represented as a percentage.
The date when the grant or pricing is effective for this quote line item.
The end date for the quote line item.
The ending quantity of the item or service in this quote line item.
The end date for the flight associated with this quote line item.
The start date for the flight associated with this quote line item.
The frequency associated with the quote line item, such as weekly or monthly.
Indicates whether this quote line item is part of the primary segment.
Indicates whether the quote line item is skippable.
The legal entity associated with this quote line item, referenced by a lookup to the Legal Entity object.
A brief description of the quote line item.
A globally unique identifier for the quote line item, automatically generated.
The line number for the quote line item, automatically generated.
The list price for the quote line item, in the specified currency.
The type of media associated with the quote line item.
The net total price for the quote line item, in the specified currency.
The net unit price for the quote line item, in the specified currency.
The number of issues or occurrences for this quote line item.
Formula field that calculates or stores the offer associated with the quote line item.
The one-time charge applied to the quote line item.
The total one-time charge applied to the quote line item.
The ID of the parent quote line item, if this is a child quote line item.
The discount percentage applied to the partner for this quote line item.
The unit price for the partner, in the specified currency.
The day associated with the period boundary for the quote line item.
The name of the placement associated with the quote line item.
Formula field that calculates or stores the placement option for the quote line item.
Lookup to the Points of Interest (POI) associated with the quote line item.
Lookup to the premises associated with the quote line item.
Unique identifier for the price waterfall associated with the quote line item.
Lookup to the pricing contract associated with the quote line item.
The pricing model applied to the quote line item.
The pricing term for the quote line item, such as monthly or annually.
The number of periods for the pricing term of the quote line item.
Lookup to the prior quote line item associated with this line item.
Lookup to the product associated with this quote line item.
Formula field that calculates or stores the product code for the quote line item.
Formula field that calculates or stores the product family for the quote line item.
The unique identifier for the product instance associated with the quote line item.
Lookup to the proration policy associated with the quote line item.
The quantity of the product or service for this quote line item.
Lookup to the unit of measure for the quantity in this quote line item.
Lookup to the quote action associated with this quote line item.
Lookup to the quote line group associated with this quote line item.
Lookup to the recipient associated with this quote line item.
The ID of the quote associated with this quote line item, referenced by a master-detail relationship.
Identifier for the ramp pricing associated with this quote line item.
The recurring charge applied to this quote line item.
The total recurring charge applied to this quote line item.
The unit price of the product or service for this quote line item.
The unique identifier for the segment associated with this quote line item.
The name of the segment associated with this quote line item.
Lookup to the service account associated with this quote line item.
The sort order for the quote line item.
The spend metric for the quote line item.
The type of spend for the quote line item.
The start date for the quote line item.
The starting quantity for the quote line item.
The status of the quote line item, such as active or completed.
The subscription term for the quote line item, expressed as a number.
The subtotal for the quote line item, excluding taxes and adjustments.
Targeting parameters for the quote line item, typically used for advertising or media.
Lookup to the tax treatment associated with the quote line item.
The total adjustment amount for the quote line item.
The total billing cost for the quote line item.
The total amount for the quote line item, including discounts and adjustments.
The total price for the quote line item, including all adjustments and taxes.
The total price for the quote line item, including taxes.
The total tax amount for the quote line item, calculated as a roll-up summary from Quote Item Tax Item.
fields.datatype: Roll-Up Summary (SUM Quote Item Tax Item)

description: The Contract object represents a legal agreement between two or more parties that outlines terms, conditions, obligations, and rights. Contracts often cover aspects such as pricing, timelines, deliverables, and obligations that are critical to managing the lifecycle of business agreements. This object also includes key attributes for tracking contract activation, renewals, amendments, and terminations, providing a comprehensive view of business operations and contractual relationships.

fields.description: The Account associated with the contract, referenced through a lookup to the Account object. This field is essential for linking the contract to the relevant business entity and for tracking the contract’s lifecycle, including renewal eligibility, account history, and customer-specific terms. It is a central field in understanding the context of the contract and its relationship to the account.

The user who activated the contract, referenced by a lookup to the User object. Tracking the activation user is important for understanding who authorized the contract's initiation and is typically used for auditing and historical reference purposes. The user’s actions may trigger automatic processes, including notifications, renewals, or other workflow-related tasks.

The date and time when the contract was activated. This timestamp is critical for calculating the contract’s start and end dates, as well as for determining the renewal eligibility and timelines. It plays a central role in contract lifecycle management, ensuring accurate tracking of contract validity periods and activation milestones.

The contract document version ID, which links to the specific version of the contract document that was signed or agreed upon. This field helps track different versions of the contract, providing version control and ensuring that all amendments or changes to the original contract are properly documented and can be referenced during renewal discussions or audits.

The ID of the amended contract, if the current contract is an amendment to a previous one. This allows businesses to manage contract history by linking related contracts together. The amended contract can reflect changes in terms, conditions, or pricing, which is particularly useful for managing ongoing relationships and ensuring that renewals align with previous agreements.

The billing address associated with the contract. This address includes information such as the street, city, state, and postal code where invoices for the contract are sent. Accurate billing information is crucial for the invoicing process, ensuring that payments are processed correctly and on time, particularly during contract renewals or periodic billing cycles.

The user who signed the contract on behalf of the company, referenced by a lookup to the User object. This signature is an essential part of the contract's formalization, establishing that the contract has been officially agreed upon and validated by the company’s representatives. It is also used for tracking accountability and triggering related processes for contract renewals or amendments.

The date when the company signed the contract. This date serves as a reference point for the contract’s lifecycle, including the initiation of the renewal period and expiration dates. It is important for ensuring that the contract renewal and other deadlines are appropriately tracked based on the company’s approval.

The number of versions associated with the contract document. This field helps track the history of contract changes and amendments over time. Keeping a count of document versions is important for legal compliance and ensuring that all parties involved are using the most current version of the contract for renewals and other contractual obligations.

The contract's end date, which marks the expiration of the terms and conditions defined in the agreement. This is a key field for tracking the timing of renewals, terminations, and amendments. The contract end date is used to generate reminders for renewal actions or to flag contracts that are nearing expiration and need review or negotiation.

The contract’s name, used as a primary identifier for the agreement in reports, dashboards, and notifications. It is the most common way to reference the contract within Salesforce and related systems. This field allows users to easily identify and search for the contract in business processes related to its lifecycle.

A unique, automatically generated number assigned to each contract. This identifier is used for referencing the contract in internal systems, reports, and legal documents. It helps avoid confusion between contracts and ensures that each contract can be uniquely identified and tracked through its lifecycle.

The user who owns the contract, typically responsible for managing the contract’s lifecycle. This includes overseeing the renewal process, addressing any issues, and ensuring compliance with the terms of the contract. The contract owner is typically the primary point of contact for all activities related to that contract.

Identifies the record type of the contract, determining the type of agreement (e.g., standard, custom, or negotiated). Record types help in managing different contract categories and enable the system to apply specific business rules, approval workflows, and renewals processes based on the type of contract.

The date when the contract begins. It is used to track the validity period and to calculate key dates such as renewal deadlines and contract expiration. This field is vital for contract lifecycle management, as it helps determine when renewal notices or reminders need to be issued.

The length of the contract term, typically measured in months. This is a critical field for understanding how long the contract is active and when it is eligible for renewal. The term defines the timeline for any automatic renewals or for triggering manual renewal actions before the contract expires.

The type of the contract, such as a fixed-term or evergreen contract. This classification impacts renewal processes, with fixed-term contracts requiring manual renewal actions and evergreen contracts typically renewing automatically unless terminated. This field helps define how the contract is managed and what actions are required for its continuation.

The contact who signed the contract on behalf of the customer. This field helps in tracking the person who authorized the contract and is typically used to initiate actions like renewal notifications, contract modifications, and follow-up communications.

The date when the customer signed the contract. This signature serves as a legal commitment to the terms of the contract and is a reference point for renewal, termination, and modification calculations.

The title or position of the person who signed the contract on behalf of the customer. This is useful for identifying decision-makers in the renewal process or in case of any issues that require authorization from a specific authority within the customer organization.

A long text description that provides detailed information about the contract, including its terms, conditions, specific clauses, and renewal information. This description may also outline any special conditions, custom terms, or restrictions that may be relevant for the renewal process or any legal considerations.

An external reference to the contract used for integration with other systems or tracking mechanisms outside of Salesforce. This field is especially useful for businesses that manage contracts in multiple systems or need to synchronize contract data with third-party systems.

Indicates whether the contract is associated with a Contract Lifecycle Management (CLM) system. This integration might automate renewal processes, trigger alerts when contracts are approaching expiration, and streamline the contract review and approval workflows.

Indicates whether the contract is a pricing contract, which can influence how pricing is structured for renewal. Pricing contracts often require recalculation or adjustment of terms during renewal, making this field important for financial and billing teams.

Indicates if the renewal process is enabled for this contract. If set to true, it means the system will track renewal dates, trigger renewal workflows, and ensure that actions are taken as the contract approaches its expiration date.

The ID of the parent contract, if the current contract is a child contract. Parent-child relationships are important for managing complex contract structures, ensuring that all terms align across linked contracts during renewals.

The ID of the previous contract if this is a renewal or amendment. It helps track the history of contractual agreements and ensures that renewal terms are consistent with prior contracts, particularly when there are amendments or changes to terms.

The pricebook associated with the contract, which defines the pricing structure for the contract. This field is essential for managing renewal pricing, ensuring that any changes in pricing models are reflected during contract renewals.

The date when the renewal notification for the contract will be sent. This field is used to trigger automated reminders for contract renewals, ensuring that the renewal process is started in a timely manner before the contract expires.
The term (in months) for the renewal notification, specifying how far in advance the renewal notice will be sent to the relevant parties.

The length of the renewal term, in months, for the contract. This field helps define the duration of the renewed contract and is essential for calculating billing cycles, service terms, and potential pricing adjustments during the renewal process.

The shipping address for the contract, relevant for physical product deliveries, renewals, or services linked to the contract. This field is also crucial for billing cycles if the contract includes physical shipments of goods.
The opportunity linked to the contract, used to track the originating sales effort and providing context for any subsequent contract renewals.

The order linked to the contract, helping connect the contract to specific sales orders. This can be important when managing product-based contracts that need to be reviewed or renewed according to order terms.

The quote linked to the contract, used for tracking the pricing and terms provided at the point of contract origination. This helps in managing renewal pricing and ensuring the contract terms align with what was initially proposed.
Any special terms or conditions associated with the contract. This could include customized renewal clauses, special discounting rules, or additional requirements that impact the renewal process.

The current status of the contract (e.g., Active, Expired, Terminated). This field is critical for identifying contracts that are nearing their end and triggering the renewal process or other follow-up actions.
The date and time when the contract was terminated. This is useful for tracking contracts that were ended before the expiration date, often impacting renewal eligibility or potential negotiations.

description: Represents a line item within a sales contract, detailing the product, quantity, price, and related information for the contract line.

fields.description: The contract associated with the sales contract line, referenced by a master-detail relationship to the Contract object.
A detailed description of the sales contract line.
The effective end date and time for the sales contract line.
The effective start date and time for the sales contract line.
The number assigned to this line item in the sales contract, used for identification and organization.
The opportunity product associated with this sales contract line, referenced by a lookup to the Opportunity Product object.
The order product associated with this sales contract line, referenced by a lookup to the Order Product object.
The original sales contract line that this line item is derived from, if applicable.
The product associated with this sales contract line, referenced by a lookup to the Product object.
The product code for the product associated with this sales contract line.
The quantity of the product or service for this sales contract line.
The quote line item associated with this sales contract line, referenced by a lookup to the Quote Line Item object.
The name of the sales contract line, typically derived from the product or service.
The current status of the sales contract line, such as active, completed, or expired.
The total price for this sales contract line, calculated based on the quantity and unit price.
The unit of measure for the product or service in this sales contract line, referenced by a lookup to the Unit of Measure object.
The unit price of the product or service for this sales contract line.
